lines.text: Enter LEONATO, ANTONIO, HERO, BEATRICE, and others

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Was not Count John here at supper

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: I saw him not.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: How tartly that gentleman looks! I never can see him but I am heartburned an hour after.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: He were an excellent man that were made just in the midway between him and Benedick: the one is too like an image and says nothing, and the other too like my ladys eldest son, evermore tattling.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Then half Signior Benedicks tongue in Count Johns mouth, and half Count Johns melancholy in Signior Benedicks face,

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: With a good leg and a good foot, uncle, and money enough in his purse, such a man would win any woman in the world, if a could get her goodwill.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: By my troth, niece, thou wilt never get thee a husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: In faith, shes too curst.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Too curst is more than curst: I shall lessen Gods sending that way for it is said, God sends a curst cow short horns but to a cow too curst he sends none.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: So, by being too curst, God will send you no horns.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Just, if he send me no husband for the which blessing I am at him upon my knees every morning and evening. Lord, I could not endure a husband with a beard on his face: I had rather lie in the woollen.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: What should I do with him dress him in my apparel and make him my waitinggentlewoman He that hath a beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no beard is less than a man: and he that is more than a youth is not for me, and he that is less than a man, I am not for him: therefore, I will even take sixpence in earnest of the bearward, and lead his apes into hell.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Well, then, go you into hell

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: No, but to the gate and there will the devil meet me, like an old cuckold, with horns on his head, and say Get you to heaven, Beatrice, get you to heaven heres no place for you maids: so deliver I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter for the heavens he shows me where the bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as the day is long.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: [To HERO]  Well, niece, I trust you will be ruled by your father.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Yes, faith it is my cousins duty to make curtsy and say Father, as it please you. But yet for all that, cousin, let him be a handsome fellow, or else make another curtsy and say Father, as it please me.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Well, niece, I hope to see you one day fitted with a husband.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Not till God make men of some other metal than earth. Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a pierce of valiant dust to make an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl No, uncle, Ill none: Adams sons are my brethren and, truly, I hold it a sin to match in my kindred.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Daughter, remember what I told you: if the prince do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: The fault will be in the music, cousin, if you be not wooed in good time: if the prince be too important, tell him there is measure in every thing and so dance out the answer. For, hear me, Hero: wooing, wedding, and repenting, is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinque pace: the first suit is hot and hasty, like a Scotch jig, and full as fantastical the wedding, mannerlymodest, as a measure, full of state and ancientry and then comes repentance and, with his bad legs, falls into the cinque pace faster and faster, till he sink into his grave.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Cousin, you apprehend passing shrewdly.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I have a good eye, uncle I can see a church by daylight.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: The revellers are entering, brother: make good room.
All put on their masks
Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, BALTHASAR, DON JOHN, BORACHIO, MARGARET, URSULA and others, masked

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Lady, will you walk about with your friend

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: So you walk softly and look sweetly and say nothing, I am yours for the walk and especially when I walk away.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: With me in your company

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: I may say so, when I please.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: And when please you to say so

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: When I like your favour for God defend the lute should be like the case!

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: My visor is Philemons roof within the house is Jove.

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: Why, then, your visor should be thatched.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Speak low, if you speak love.
Drawing her aside

lines.speaker: balthasar
lines.text: Well, I would you did like me.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: So would not I, for your own sake for I have many illqualities.

lines.speaker: balthasar
lines.text: Which is one

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: I say my prayers aloud.

lines.speaker: balthasar
lines.text: I love you the better: the hearers may cry, Amen.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: God match me with a good dancer!

lines.speaker: balthasar
lines.text: Amen.

lines.speaker: margaret
lines.text: And God keep him out of my sight when the dance is done! Answer, clerk.

lines.speaker: balthasar
lines.text: No more words: the clerk is answered.

lines.speaker: ursula
lines.text: I know you well enough you are Signior Antonio.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: At a word, I am not.

lines.speaker: ursula
lines.text: I know you by the waggling of your head.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

lines.speaker: ursula
lines.text: You could never do him so illwell, unless you were the very man. Heres his dry hand up and down: you are he, you are he.

lines.speaker: antonio
lines.text: At a word, I am not.

lines.speaker: ursula
lines.text: Come, come, do you think I do not know you by your excellent wit can virtue hide itself Go to, mum, you are he: graces will appear, and theres an end.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Will you not tell me who told you so

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: No, you shall pardon me.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Nor will you not tell me who you are

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Not now.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: That I was disdainful, and that I had my good wit out of the Hundred Merry Tales:well this was Signior Benedick that said so.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Whats he

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I am sure you know him well enough.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Not I, believe me.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Did he never make you laugh

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I pray you, what is he

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Why, he is the princes jester: a very dull fool only his gift is in devising impossible slanders: none but libertines delight in him and the commendation is not in his wit, but in his villany for he both pleases men and angers them, and then they laugh at him and beat him. I am sure he is in the fleet: I would he had boarded me.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: When I know the gentleman, Ill tell him what you say.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Do, do: hell but break a comparison or two on me which, peradventure not marked or not laughed at, strikes him into melancholy and then theres a partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no supper that night. We must follow the leaders.
Music

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: In every good thing.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next turning.
Dance. Then exeunt all except DON JOHN, BORACHIO, and CLAUDIO

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath withdrawn her father to break with him about it. The ladies follow her and but one visor remains.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: Are not you Signior Benedick

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: You know me well I am he.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: Signior, you are very near my brother in his love: he is enamoured on Hero I pray you, dissuade him from her: she is no equal for his birth: you may do the part of an honest man in it.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: How know you he loves her

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: I heard him swear his affection.

lines.speaker: borachio
lines.text: So did I too and he swore he would marry her tonight.

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: Come, let us to the banquet.
Exeunt DON JOHN and BORACHIO

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Thus answer I in the name of Benedick, But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio. Tis certain so the prince wooes for himself. Friendship is constant in all other things Save in the office and affairs of love: Therefore, all hearts in love use their own tongues Let every eye negotiate for itself And trust no agent for beauty is a witch Against whose charms faith melteth into blood. This is an accident of hourly proof, Which I mistrusted not. Farewell, therefore, Hero!
Reenter BENEDICK

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Count Claudio

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Yea, the same.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Come, will you go with me

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Whither

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Even to the next willow, about your own business, county. What fashion will you wear the garland of about your neck, like an usurers chain or under your arm, like a lieutenants scarf You must wear it one way, for the prince hath got your Hero.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I wish him joy of her.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Why, thats spoken like an honest drovier: so they sell bullocks. But did you think the prince would have served you thus

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I pray you, leave me.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Ho! now you strike like the blind man: twas the boy that stole your meat, and youll beat the post.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: If it will not be, Ill leave you.
Exit

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Alas, poor hurt fowl! now will he creep into sedges. But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me! The princes fool! Ha It may be I go under that title because I am merry. Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong I am not so reputed: it is the base, though bitter, disposition of Beatrice that puts the world into her person and so gives me out. Well, Ill be revenged as I may.
Reenter DON PEDRO

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Now, signior, wheres the count did you see him

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Troth, my lord, I have played the part of Lady Fame. I found him here as melancholy as a lodge in a warren: I told him, and I think I told him true, that your grace had got the good will of this young lady and I offered him my company to a willowtree, either to make him a garland, as being forsaken, or to bind him up a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: To be whipped! Whats his fault

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: The flat transgression of a schoolboy, who, being overjoyed with finding a birds nest, shows it his companion, and he steals it.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Wilt thou make a trust a transgression The transgression is in the stealer.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been made, and the garland too for the garland he might have worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on you, who, as I take it, have stolen his birds nest.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: I will but teach them to sing, and restore them to the owner.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: If their singing answer your saying, by my faith, you say honestly.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the gentleman that danced with her told her she is much wronged by you.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: O, she misused me past the endurance of a block! an oak but with one green leaf on it would have answered her my very visor began to assume life and scold with her. She told me, not thinking I had been myself, that I was the princes jester, that I was duller than a great thaw huddling jest upon jest with such impossible conveyance upon me that I stood like a man at a mark, with a whole army shooting at me. She speaks poniards, and every word stabs: if her breath were as terrible as her terminations, there were no living near her she would infect to the north star. I would not marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam bad left him before he transgressed: she would have made Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to make the fire too. Come, talk not of her: you shall find her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God some scholar would conjure her for certainly, while she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary and people sin upon purpose, because they would go thither so, indeed, all disquiet, horror and perturbation follows her.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Look, here she comes.
Enter CLAUDIO, BEATRICE, HERO, and LEONATO

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Will your grace command me any service to the worlds end I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on I will fetch you a toothpicker now from the furthest inch of Asia, bring you the length of Prester Johns foot, fetch you a hair off the great Chams beard, do you any embassage to the Pigmies, rather than hold three words conference with this harpy. You have no employment for me

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: None, but to desire your good company.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: O God, sir, heres a dish I love not: I cannot endure my Lady Tongue.
Exit

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Come, lady, come you have lost the heart of Signior Benedick.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Indeed, my lord, he lent it me awhile and I gave him use for it, a double heart for his single one: marry, once before he won it of me with false dice, therefore your grace may well say I have lost it.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: You have put him down, lady, you have put him down.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: So I would not he should do me, my lord, lest I should prove the mother of fools. I have brought Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Why, how now, count! wherefore are you sad

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Not sad, my lord.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: How then sick

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Neither, my lord.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: The count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry, nor well but civil count, civil as an orange, and something of that jealous complexion.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: I faith, lady, I think your blazon to be true though, Ill be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false. Here, Claudio, I have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won: I have broke with her father, and his good will obtained: name the day of marriage, and God give thee joy!

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes: his grace hath made the match, and an grace say Amen to it.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Speak, count, tis your cue.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Silence is the perfectest herald of joy: I were but little happy, if I could say how much. Lady, as you are mine, I am yours: I give away myself for you and dote upon the exchange.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Speak, cousin or, if you cannot, stop his mouth with a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: In faith, lady, you have a merry heart.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Yea, my lord I thank it, poor fool, it keeps on the windy side of care. My cousin tells him in his ear that he is in her heart.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: And so she doth, cousin.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Good Lord, for alliance! Thus goes every one to the world but I, and I am sunburnt I may sit in a corner and cry heighho for a husband!

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I would rather have one of your fathers getting. Hath your grace neer a brother like you Your father got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Will you have me, lady

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: No, my lord, unless I might have another for workingdays: your grace is too costly to wear every day. But, I beseech your grace, pardon me: I was born to speak all mirth and no matter.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Your silence most offends me, and to be merry best becomes you for, out of question, you were born in a merry hour.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: No, sure, my lord, my mother cried but then there was a star danced, and under that was I born. Cousins, God give you joy!

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I cry you mercy, uncle. By your graces pardon.
Exit

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: By my troth, a pleasantspirited lady.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Theres little of the melancholy element in her, my lord: she is never sad but when she sleeps, and not ever sad then for I have heard my daughter say, she hath often dreamed of unhappiness and waked herself with laughing.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: O, by no means: she mocks all her wooers out of suit.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: She were an excellent wife for Benedict.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they would talk themselves mad.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Tomorrow, my lord: time goes on crutches till love have all his rites.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Not till Monday, my dear son, which is hence a just sevennight and a time too brief, too, to have all things answer my mind.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing: but, I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go dully by us. I will in the interim undertake one of Hercules labours which is, to bring Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of affection the one with the other. I would fain have it a match, and I doubt not but to fashion it, if you three will but minister such assistance as I shall give you direction.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights watchings.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: And I, my lord.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: And you too, gentle Hero

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a good husband.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that I know. Thus far can I praise him he is of a noble strain, of approved valour and confirmed honesty. I will teach you how to humour your cousin, that she shall fall in love with Benedick and I, with your two helps, will so practise on Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy stomach, he shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this, Cupid is no longer an archer: hi s glory shall be ours, for we are the only lovegods. Go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.
Exeunt
